data.title: Can no longer open image files from the git viewlet
data.body:
fixes #33739 

The SCM viewlet is always using `window.showTextDocument` when clicking on a file in the list of outgoing changes, however this will fail with an error if the file is binary. Previously it was using the `vscode.open` command which handled this nicely. However, that was changed via https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/commit/c0381f2b62b9bf1b3d81f9f88b82a9eb5bd873dc to support more options when opening actual text files.

This fix adds `TextDocumentShowOptions` to the `vscode.open` command so that binary files can also be opened. 

I realize we had this request going on already via https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/pull/30675 but at that time I did not see the issue with binary files.

data.title: load user and extension snippets only when needed
data.body: This will fix #33158 and also improve startup performance because snippets are only loaded when needed.

data.title: Explorer: dropping file with same name overwrites without confirmation
data.body:
Steps to Reproduce:

1. drop a file to the explorer from outside VSCode into a folder where a file with that name already exists
2. the file is being replaced without confirmation

=> this is data loss because we even loose dirty changes if the file is dirty

data.title: High CPU usage when viewing workbench.main.js source in Developer Tools
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode. -->

<!-- Use Help > Report Issues to prefill these. -->
- VSCode Version: 1.16.0-insider x64 (and 1.15.1 x86)
- OS Version: Windows 8.1 64bit

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Open Developer Tools, Sources tab
2. Navigate to and select **workbench.main.js** in `file://Program Files/Microsoft VS Code Insiders/resources/app/out/vs/workbench`
3. Observe high CPU usage which locks Developer Tools for a few minutes or longer.
4. Closing Developer Tools will stop high CPU usage, which will resume if Developer Tools is opened again.

<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Reproduces without extensions: Yes

Even without pretty-printing the minified file, the workbench.main.js source file takes a very long time to load with high CPU usage. While it's loading, the Developer Tools is completely frozen.  Sometimes I end up on this file's source while debugging extensions, but this is not extension-dependant.

The load takes a few minutes, but after load completes, CPU usage returns to normal, and the file source can then be closed.  If the file source is not closed, reopening Developer Tools will again cause high CPU usage.  You can't use Developer Tools after this happens unless you wait a long time for the file to load or to try to quickly close the file source before the CPU locks up.

data.title: Database corruption issue preventing VS Code from launching
data.body:
<!-- Use Help > Report Issues to prefill these. -->
- VSCode Version: 1.15.1
- OS Version: 10.12.6 (occurred with latest 10.11 as well)

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Download VS Code 1.15.1
2. Open it, via CLI `code` or by double-clicking icon

<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Reproduces without extensions: Yes

I have an iMac, and a Macbook. Both have very similar specs and both are running the same version of both VSCode and macOS.

On the Macbook, VS Code runs wonderfully and I have no issues.

On the iMac, VS Code used to run wonderfully without issue. Without making any changes, to my system.

I've solved this issue on my own, but I was not able to find a resource here which assisted.
Therefore, I'm going to open and immediately close this issue so in the future those like me have a search result to turn to.

I force-killed VS Code during startup once, and it left the sqlite database in an unreadable state.

I was able to identify the issue by launching from the `code` CLI in verbose mode.

(if you're having a similar issue but my fix doesn't assist you, that's a place to start)

In order to return VS Code to a working state, I had to delete `/Users/<my username>/Library/Application Support/Code/Workspaces/Code`

This allowed VS Code to re-create the damaged DB and start normally.

data.title: Word wrap resets to default value when saving or renaming file

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.15.1 (41abd21afdf7424c89319ee7cb0445cc6f376959, 2017-08-16T17:16:27.618Z)
- OS Version: Linux x64 4.10.0-27-generic

Without any extensions or custom user/workspace settings, word wrap always turns off when saving a file or renaming the current file from the explorer sidebar.

---

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Press Ctrl+N and type a long line.
2. Press Alt+Z to enable word wrap.
3. Save the file and note that word wrap has been disabled.
4. Re-enable word wrap and rename the current file. Word wrap should disable again.

Expected behaviour: I think the word wrap setting should stay the same when editing a file, no matter whether its name or location changes.

<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Reproduces without extensions: Yes

data.title: allThreadsContinued not respected
data.body:
_From @DatGuyJonathan on August 31, 2017 22:0_

I'm working on a debugger extension that supports multiple stopped threads. When the user clicks 'continue', the debug adapter (DA) handles continueRequest with the backend and responds to VS Code with allThreadsContinued = false. The backend will eventually notify DA that the thread has finished, so DA sends a ThreadEvent with reason 'exited' to VS Code.

If I have multiple stopped threads and perform 'continue' on one of them, VS Code removes all the threads from the call stack view. My workaround is to send a stopped event to VS Code for every thread that the DA knows about, but that seems expensive because the DA will have to handle stackTraceRequest for threads that haven't changed.

Is that workaround the expected behavior from DA?

Here are the versions I'm working with:
VS Code: 1.15.0
vscode-debugadapter & vscode-debugprotocol: 1.22.0



_Copied from original issue: Microsoft/vscode-debugadapter-node#130_

data.title: adapt debug adapters to new DebugConfigurationProvider
Switch to official "loaded scripts" debug API
Text is pasted into integrated terminal instead of search box
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.15.1 64-bit
- OS Version: Windows 10

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Copy some text to clipboard
2. Go to integrated terminal (powershell in my case)
3. Open search box (ctrl-f)
4. Paste copied text into search box.

Behavior:
![pasting-in-terminal](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/9638275/30054875-dd9b3652-922d-11e7-824d-2d01177a28a7.gif)

Text is pasted into terminal instead of terminal search box, or in both places. Right-click on Find field in the box to paste from context menu also pastes the text into terminal, even without explicitly selecting Paste from context menu. This changes depending on focus, sometimes closing and opening search box changes behavior slightly, but it still appears in one or other way.

data.title: [loc][Query][VSCode] Please clarify meaning
data.body:
Hi, we have a question from a translator. Could you help please?

Source:
Controls what changes are discarded by the `Discard all changes` command. `all` discards all changes. `tracked` discards only tracked files. `prompt` shows a prompt dialog every time the action is run.

---

File Name:
extensions/git/package.nls.json

Query:

The translation of some of the UI options could not be verified. Left in English with a suggestion in brackets in accordance with the instructions.

Ex. ( de-de 
Legt fest, welche Änderungen vom Befehl "Alle Änderungen verwerfen" verworfen werden. "alle" verwirft alle Änderungen. "tracked" (verfolgt) verwirft nur verfolgte Dateien. "prompt" (Eingabeaufforderung) zeigt immer eine Eingabeaufforderung an, wenn die Aktion ausgeführt wird. )

Steps to Reproduce:

**1. debug npm scripts**
```json
{
  "version": "0.2.0",
  "configurations": [
    {
      "type": "node",
      "request": "launch",
      "name": "Launch via NPM",
      "runtimeExecutable": "npm",
      "runtimeArgs": [
        "run-script",
        "debug"
      ],
      // "console": "integratedTerminal",
      "port": 9229
    }
  ]
}
```

---

**2. when use `"console": "integratedTerminal"`**

- it will start cluster with debug execArgv

data.title: [loc][Query][VSCode] Please clarify meaning
data.body:
Hi, we have a question from a translator. Could you help please?

Source:
Controls sorting order of files and folders in the explorer. In addition to the default sorting, you can set the order to 'mixed' (files and folders sorted combined), 'type' (by file type), 'modified' (by last modified date) or 'filesFirst' (sort files before folders).

File Name:
src/vs/workbench/parts/files/browser/files.contribution.ts

Query:
Please advise whether the options "mixed", "type", "modified" and "filesFirst" are localizable. Left in English for the time being since concatenated words suchas "filesFirst" are usually not localizable.Please confirm
--

data.title: Implement Find All command & button
data.body:
Description
---
Implements a Find All command and button which selects and adds multicursors to all matches in the file. This functionality is available in Sublime and I was a bit jealous, so I've decided I would implement it for VS Code. I understand that this contains a change to the UI, so I won't be upset if the UX team rejects this pull request, as I haven't discussed this feature with anyone before implementing it.

Usage examples
---
Simple editing using multi-cursors:
![find-all-simple](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/786473/30051088-62c0595c-9229-11e7-91ed-9f0d9f4da598.gif)

Extracting matches:
![find-all-extract-text](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/786473/30051105-719ad0f6-9229-11e7-80df-9193c65d4346.gif)

Further info
---
This pull request contains a placeholder icon I hacked up from other icons in VS Code's source, and it probably doesn't really match VS Code's search iconography.
This pull request doesn't contain any localisations.

data.title: JS - feature request - detect object Event as the first argument in func
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode. -->

<!-- Use Help > Report Issues to prefill these. -->
- VSCode Version: 1.16.0 ins
- OS Version: win7x64

Feature request about specific snippets for "current" elem or object, that we write.

For example, object Event. That comes as the first argument in function-handler.
The snippets, like `stopPropagation`, is bound to the specific name "event":

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/24613274/30047312-2640a334-9219-11e7-972d-801107d914e7.png)

and it cannot detect the "e", as the default Event object, that comes as the first argument:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/24613274/30047269-df966fae-9218-11e7-956a-1044f52cd754.png)

The argument can be "e", "ev", "evt", etc. That's not about adding new names to the detection list, but, if possible, to learn VS Code to detect that first combination of letters in the parenthesis, make VS Code understand, that it's the Event object, so it could make `"event" == "e"` but itself.
It's not critical, but it would make the VS Code a little bit smarter.

data.title: Go to Definition files to open in read only mode
data.body:
There is a [feature request](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode-go/issues/1190) to the Go extension to open files from the standard library in a read only mode when user navigates to them using the Go to Definition feature for example.

This would need us to update the api for the definition provider to return the extra info of whether the file at given location should be opened in read only mode or not.
Then the code that does the actual navigation need to be updated to open a read only mode of the file.

On the other hand, extensions can themselves create a new command that does this using the [TextDocumentContentProvider](https://code.visualstudio.com/docs/extensionAPI/vscode-api#_a-nametextdocumentcontentprovideraspan-classcodeitem-id458textdocumentcontentproviderspan). But the downside is that the real `Go to Definition` cmd still exists and will invariably get used by the user.

@Microsoft/vscode Thoughts?
